title: Avoid Using ID Attributes
description: Don't use the id attribute in markup unless absolutely certain it will be unique. IDs must be unique across the entire page.

rationale: IDs must be unique on a page. In Drupal's modular system, multiple modules or blocks might use the same ID, causing conflicts and JavaScript errors.
fix_guidance: Replace IDs with classes. If an ID is absolutely necessary, use an incrementing approach (e.g., #your-id-0, #your-id-1) or ensure uniqueness through prefixing.

title: Every Div Must Have a Class
description: Every div element must have at least one identifying class. It's better to have too many classes than not enough.
rationale: Classes provide hooks for CSS styling and JavaScript functionality. Without classes, it's impossible to target elements reliably across different contexts.
fix_guidance: Add descriptive classes to all div elements. Use multiple classes to describe object type, state, and unique identifiers.

title: Use Three Types of Classes
description: Use three types of classes on elements: 1) Object type (node/user/message), 2) Variation/state (full/teaser/collapsed), 3) Unique identifier (node-123).

fix_guidance: Add classes following the pattern: [object-type] [object-variation] [object-id]. This provides multiple hooks for CSS and JavaScript.

title: Use Semantic HTML Elements
description: Prefer semantic HTML elements over generic divs and spans. Add classes to existing elements instead of wrapping them.

rationale: Semantic HTML improves accessibility, SEO, and code maintainability. It provides meaning to content structure that benefits screen readers and search engines.
fix_guidance: Replace generic divs with semantic elements like header, nav, main, article, section, aside, footer. Use heading tags (h1-h6) for titles.

title: Site Title Should Use H1 with ID
description: The site title should use an h1 element with id='site-name' for consistent styling and structure.
examples:
{"bad": ["
My Site
", "

My Site

", "

My Site

rationale: Consistent markup for site titles ensures proper heading hierarchy and allows for reliable styling across all Drupal sites.
fix_guidance: Use <h1 id='site-name'> for the main site title. This is an exception to the 'avoid IDs' rule as site-name is guaranteed to be unique.

title: Page Title Structure
description: Page titles should use h1 with class='title' and id='page-title' for consistent page structure.
examples:

rationale: Consistent page title markup ensures proper heading hierarchy and provides reliable hooks for styling and JavaScript.
fix_guidance: Use <h1 class='title' id='page-title'> for page titles. This provides both class and ID hooks for maximum flexibility.

title: Use H2 for Subheadings and Block Titles
description: Subheadings and block titles should use h2 elements for proper heading hierarchy.
examples:

Recent Posts

rationale: Proper heading hierarchy improves accessibility and document structure. Screen readers use heading levels to navigate content.
fix_guidance: Use h2 for all subheadings and block titles. This maintains a logical heading structure: h1 for site/page title, h2 for sections.

title: Avoid Presentational HTML Tags
description: Avoid using presentational tags like <b> and <i>. Use semantic alternatives like <strong> and <em>.
examples: {"bad": ["Bold text", "Italic text", "Underlined text"], "good": ["Bold text", "Italic text", "Underlined text"]}
rationale: Semantic tags convey meaning, not just visual styling. <strong> indicates importance, while <b> only indicates bold styling.
fix_guidance: Replace <b> with <strong>, <i> with <em>. For purely visual effects, use CSS classes instead of presentational tags.

title: Use Block-Level Elements for Content Containers
description: Use block-level elements (div) for containing content, not inline elements like span.
examples:
{"bad": ["Paragraph of text", "Block content"], "good": ["
Paragraph of text
", "
Block content
"]}
rationale: Block-level elements are designed for layout and content structure. Using inline elements for layout can cause rendering issues.
fix_guidance: Use div or semantic block elements (section, article, aside) for content containers. Reserve span for inline text styling.

title: Validate HTML and CSS
description: Regularly validate HTML and CSS using W3C validators to ensure standards compliance.
examples:

rationale: Valid HTML and CSS ensure consistent rendering across browsers and improve accessibility. Invalid markup can cause JavaScript errors and layout issues.
fix_guidance: Use W3C HTML Validator and CSS Validator regularly. Fix all errors and review warnings. Use WAVE tool for accessibility validation.
